Text 1.4: The dimension of a non-empty affine set is defined as the dimension of the subspace parallel to it. (The dimension of : ?m.1 is -1 : -1 by convention.)

noncomputable def affineSetDim (n : Nat) (M : Set (Fin n -> Real)) (hM : IsAffineSet n M) : Int := by classical by_cases hne : Set.Nonempty M let L : Submodule Real (Fin n -> Real) := Classical.choose (parallel_submodule_unique_of_affine n M hM hne).exists exact Int.ofNat (Module.finrank Real L) exact -1

Text 1.5: An affine set of dimension 0 : 0 is called a point.

def IsPoint (n : Nat) (M : Set (Fin n -> Real)) : Prop := hM : IsAffineSet n M, affineSetDim n M hM = 0

Text 1.5: An affine set of dimension 1 : 1 is called a line.

def IsLine (n : Nat) (M : Set (Fin n -> Real)) : Prop := hM : IsAffineSet n M, affineSetDim n M hM = 1

Text 1.5: An affine set of dimension 2 : 2 is called a plane.

def IsPlane (n : Nat) (M : Set (Fin n -> Real)) : Prop := hM : IsAffineSet n M, affineSetDim n M hM = 2

Text 1.5: An sorry - 1 : (Unknown identifier `n`n - 1)-dimensional affine set in ^ sorry : TypeReal^Unknown identifier `n`n is called a hyperplane.
